statement.text: The smallest detectable power corresponds to single-photon detection rates. A single visible photon per second represents ~3 × 10⁻¹⁹ W. Optical power meters achieve ~10⁻¹⁵ W (femtowatt) sensitivity. Bolometers and transition edge sensors reach ~10⁻¹⁸ W (attowatt). There is NO fundamental minimum power—it can be arbitrarily small. The Planck power (Pₚ ≈ 3.6 × 10⁵² W) is NOT a minimum—it's enormous.
statement.formal: Single visible photon/s: ~3 × 10⁻¹⁹ W; Power meter: ~10⁻¹⁵ W; Bolometer: ~10⁻¹⁸ W; Planck: 3.6 × 10⁵² W

explanation.intuition: Power = Energy/Time. The smallest power corresponds to the lowest detectable energy (single photons) over the longest measurement time. A photon counter detecting one visible photon per second measures ~10⁻¹⁹ W. The Planck power (~10⁵² W) is NOT minimum—it's the power output of the entire observable universe (~10⁵² W) coincidentally matching Planck power.
explanation.key_insight: There is no fundamental minimum power because both energy and time can vary. A microwave photon per minute is ~10⁻²⁶ W. Practical limits come from detector noise (thermal, amplifier). Gravitational wave energy flux at Earth from binary black holes is ~10⁻³ W/m², extremely low power density.

comparison_with_planck.interpretation: Planck power equals the luminosity of the observable universe. It's definitely NOT a minimum.

related.relationship: Planck power is NOT minimum—it's 10⁵² W
